captions.text:
The pistol and mantis shrimps are both crustaceans
that snap their claws and perform magic. Well,

at least a sound and light show: the jet of
water squeezed out from between their claws

travels at such speeds that it cavitates - the
liquid water under negative pressure is literally

pulled apart into bubbles of water vapor.
When the bubbles collapse in on themselves,

they give off a loud "snap," and amazingly,
a small flash of light. The shrimp use the

sonic shock wave to stun or kill prey, but
physicists are far more interested in the

flash of light, because we still don't exactly
know why it happens.

Collapsing bubbles can also be created in
a laboratory simply by using sound - since

sound, as we know, is basically just molecules
repeatedly pushing against each other and

then pulling apart, if the sound waves are
intense enough, the low pressure will again

be low enough to pull the liquid apart into
vapor and cause cavitation bubbles. The bubbles

then collapse, and under certain circumstances,
they produce light even brighter than the

shrimp. This phenomenon of turning sound into
light is called "sonoluminescence."

We know that the light flashes are incredibly
short - lasting only about 100 picoseconds

- and are surprisingly high energy, meaning
the collapsing bubbles may be up to 10 times
hotter than the surface of the sun.

We don't know for sure, though, how the inside
of the bubble gets that hot, or what exactly

is giving off the light. The bubble collapses
so quickly that the gases inside are heated

by compression, but the increased pressure
might also cause water vapor in the bubble

to rapidly condense back to a liquid, releasing
large amounts of latent heat.

And the flash itself might come from glowing
red-hot Argon or Xenon gas in the air bubble,

OR from heat tearing water vapor apart into
hydroxide and hydrogen ions which then recombine

and give off light, OR from the whole interior
of the bubble getting hot enough to become
a glowing plasma - OR it might be a combination.

Either way, the cool thing about sonoluminescence
is that it's still not fully understood despite

being fairly simple to create - I mean, you
can buy a basic sonoluminescence kit off the
web! Or just get a pet mantis shrimp.

If you want to hear about more unexplained
phenomena in science, a whole bunch of youtubers

like vsauce, veritasium, thebrainscoop, and
so forth have made videos about "unanswered

science questions" which you can find listed
in the "All Time 10s" video of the same name.

title: How to Turn Sound Into Light: Sonoluminescence

comments.text:
+MinutePhysics I can't believe I'm contradicting the physics guru himself, 
but this is a biology thing. The PISTOL shrimp has the large claw and 
shoots its prey with superheated water bubbles, as described in the video. 
Whereas the mantis shrimp is simply amazing in its own right, ferocious 
predator that it is, it doesn't shoot jets of water. Instead it has the 
worlds fastest punch, utilizing modified front claws in a catapult-like 
motion, the mantis shrimp cracks the hard-shelled crustaceans it prefers, 
while the pistol shrimp will most often hunt smaller shrimps and fishes. ﻿
comments.author: 7catstied2gether

comments.text:
I think that  Sonoluminescence and Triboluminescence work by the same 
principle. and i am sure that there are no gases involved here. (the 
addition of more kinetic energy makes the electron to displace itself 
resulting in giving out photons. if the electron displaces more, it might 
show blue and vice versa 4 red)﻿

comments.text:
A) It would be easy to disprove the hot noble gases explanation by removing 
these from the air and looking for a change in the light emitted, or by 
using spectroscopy to identify the elements emitting light.

B) Couldn't you also use spectroscopy to show if splitting water molecules 
was the explanation, as specific wavelengths would be emitted?

C) Using the results from the tests above, I think you could calculate the 
amount of light that is emitted due to it being plasma.

Please correct me if I am wrong.﻿

comments.author: Artur R

comments.text:
So, some people have a hypothesis that this is actually fusion between the 
atoms of water. A guy tested this, supposedly had the neutron emissions to 
back it up, but he was dispelled from the scientific community for all 
sorts of peer-review violations. 

If this is actually true, then it would likely solve our energy problem.

If this isn't true, then the law of thermodynamics is stopping us from 
making this into a renewable source of energy. We will never get more 
energy out than we put in.

average person, who can then look further into it if they find it 
interesting.

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure you can test what causes it, just use a different pure 
 liquid and if it shows the same effect you know it's not anything to do 
with impurities and that it's not a property of water itself but of 
liquids. If it doesn't work in other liquids that lends itself more towards 
it being a property of water.
I wonder if it's possible to get this to work in liquid hydrogen, it seems 
like a similar effect to what they're trying to do in fusion reactors, 
without the laser energy waste.﻿
comments.author: mynameismatt2010

comments.text:
Testing other liquids is not a bad idea, but in any experiment you want to 
control every factor that could affect it. Thus, I have no doubt they used 
destilled water to avoid impurities. As a biology science undergratuate 
that's usually the first thing we consider when doing experiments that 
needs water. Sometimes we use some REALLY expensive machines just to be 
sure the water is as free of impurities as possible (and that means 
99,999...% pure water).

comments.author: Noa Galtung

comments.text:
Water has dissolved ambient air in it. There are trace amounts of all 
gasses in water, mainly nitrogen and oxygen. As the vacuum void is created 
within the water, these dissolved gasses escape into the void. As the void 
collapses, these gasses become excited and give off photons.

comments.text:
So, if something gets compressed nearly to its schwarzschild radius, it 
will heat up. So... If wouldn't that mean that a black hole has 
temperature, because if you compress something to its schwarzschild radius, 
its density would instantly become infinite... But how hot would it be? 
Like you said in this video, if the bubble compressed small enough and 
becomes a temperature hotter than the sun, but for a short time... How hot 
would a black hole be? Would it go higher than the Planck Temperature? 
Well... After the Planck Temperature, its not necessarily a temperature. 
But, if there is a speed of light, speed of sound, is there a speed of... 
temperature? If there is the speed obviously has to be slower than both 
sound and light, but would it instantly be sucked into the black hole 
meaning nothing even though it once existed.

This is a very big question on my part, please explain it in a video.﻿
comments.author: Reece Holmdahl

comments.text:
Hey Reece, well first of all, there is the difference, that stuff going 
into a black hole is not being compressed by an external force, but being 
dragged in by gravity and matter actually has to give off heat (energy in 
form of e.g. radiation) to circle closer to the black hole. However one can 
still easily use at least one video trying to explain the dynamics of a 
black hole - basically our math/physics is probably inadequate to probably 
explain these yet.

it can do simply with it own claws.﻿

possible. e.g. in the sun, protons fuse together to cores of heavier 
elements all the way up to zinc. (the more mass, the further it gets in the 
chain, look up silicon burning process at Wikipedia).
